title.narrative: IR 1.1.3: HEALTH NUTRITION HYGIENE HIV

description.narrative: 1.1.3. Women, adolescents, children, families and communities are mobilized and adopt healthy practices in primary health care, nutrition, hygiene, HIV prevention in regular and emergency situations, using a gender approach., which contributes to Adolescents And Hiv/Aids, Early Childhood Development, Health And Emergencies, Health â€“ General, Hiv â€“ General, Hygiene, Maternal And Newborn Health, Nutrition And Emergencies, Sanitation, Treatment And Care Of Children Living With Hiv, Treatment Of Severe Acute Malnutrition, Wash And Emergencies, Wash In Schools And Ecd Centres, Water. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: 1.1. Reduction of maternal mortality, infant and neonatal mortality, and reduction of chronic malnutrition and HIV vertical transmission.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: 1.1.3. Women, adolescents, children, families and communities are mobilized and adopt healthy practices in primary health care,nutrition, hygiene, HIV prevention in regular and emergency situations, using a gender approach.
Number of people in humanitarian situations accessing sufficient quantity of water, appropriate quality for drinking, cooking and personal hygiene
Number of people in humanitarian situations using appropriate sanitation facilities
Percentage of children < 5 years in humanitarian situations accessing Vitamin A supplements

actual.value: 2014:% of children not available. BCO delivered 240,000 doses of vitamin A in drought emergencies in Santa Cruz, Cochabamba, Tarija y Chuquisaca and 150,000 doses in flood emergencies in Beni.

title.narrative: Percentage of schools from the intervention area using life skills for preventing STI/HIV, violence and unplanned pregnancies
% of mothers, fathers and care takers knowing and practicing the 3 key hygiene practices with their children < 2 years of age

actual.value: 2014:BCO advocated and provided techical assistance to include hygiene indicators in National Health Information System. Will be available in 2015.
